title: Pulborough Walks

images.title: Simon Carey / Footpaths to Pulborough
images.caption: Following the course of both footpaths as they cross the flood plain of the Arun back towards Pulborough perched on higher ground.

images.title: Nigel Cox / River Arun: Levée south of Pulborough
images.caption: River Arun: Levée south of Pulborough. The Arun is tidal along this reach and the water meadows on either side are protected from inundation by the levées on either side of the river. The RSPB Pulborough Brooks reserve is to the left.

images.title: Simon Carey / Pulborough Brooks
images.caption: View over Pulborough Brooks. Brooks is a Sussex term to describe the wetlands of a river's flood plain.

images.title: Nigel Cox / River Arun south of Pulborough
images.caption: River Arun south of Pulborough. The Arun is tidal in this reach and about thirty metres wide.

images.title: Nigel Cox / Pulborough Brooks RSPB site and flood meadow
images.caption: Pulborough Brooks RSPB site and flood meadow. This is the north-eastern corner of the Pulborough Brooks RSPB site which covers the flood plain on the east side of the River Arun here. It is grazed by cattle.

images.title: Nigel Cox / River Stor near Pulborough
images.caption: River Stor near Pulborough. The River Stor is a tributary of the River Arun and flows into the latter just downstream of Pulborough. Because the Arun is tidal in this reach and because there are no structures on the Stor to control the flow of water the Stor itself is tidal here too. However there are large earth embankments on either side of the river here to constrain any high water levels.

images.title: Simon Carey / View Across Pulborough Brooks
images.caption: View Across Pulborough Brooks. Taken from higher ground to the south east of the square which is RSPB land and contains a number of their hides. If you look closely you can see a golden line running through the middle of the brooks this is roughly the site of the Sussex Greensand Way a Roman road that ran from Stane Street east to Barcombe. It crossed the brooks by means of a causeway some of which still exists.

images.title: Simon Carey / Rivermead, Pulborough
images.caption: Rivermead. The road overlooks the Pulborough Brooks and South Downs.

description: This large village is located on the northern edge of the South Downs in the Horsham district of West Sussex. Near the village there's nice riverside walks along the River Arun, some pretty nature reserves and large woodland areas. This circular walk from the village visits the Pulborough Brooks Nature Reserve to the south of the village. Start the walk from the car park at the southern edge of the village. From here you can pick up footpaths heading south to the RSPB reserve where you'll find wetlands and nature trails. Look out for wildlife including Peregrine Falcon, Lapwing and Wigeon as you maked your way around the site. There's also some good views across the South Downs to enjoy from the paths. Follow the footpaths south and they will take you towards Wiggonholt. There's the option here of taking a detour south to visit Wiggonholt Common where there are some nice woodland trails. This walk heads north past Lickfold towards Marehill, before heading through the village to return to the car park.
